<!--https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/can#can__2-->
<h1><i class="i">Can</i></h1>            <div class="fcdo-s20">from <a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/english-grammar-today/" class="a--rev">English Grammar Today</a></div>
</div><div class="content"><div class="section_anchor" id="can-forms"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Can</i>: forms</h2></div><div class="content"><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Affirmative (+) form</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Can</i> comes first <span class="target"/>in the verb phrase (after the subject and before another verb):</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[verb phrase]</span><span class="rb"><b class="b">can</b> take</span></span> the train to Birmingham.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p"><i class="i">Can</i> is never used with another modal verb:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He <b class="b">can</b> hear the music from his room sometimes.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">He can might hear the music</s> … or <s class="s">He might can might hear the music</s> …</p></blockquote></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Negative (−) form</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">The negative form of <i class="i">can</i> is <i class="i">can’t</i>. We don’t use <i class="i">don’t</i>/<i class="i">doesn’t</i>/<i class="i">didn’t</i> with <i class="i">can</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">can’t</b> believe you said that!</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">I don’t can believe you said that!</s></p></blockquote><p class="p">We can use the full form <i class="i">cannot</i> (one word) in formal contexts or when we want to emphasise something:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">cannot</b> understand why she behaves like that.</i></p></blockquote><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modality-forms">Modality: forms </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Question (?) form</h3></div><div class="content"><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Warning: </span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><p class="p">The subject and <i class="i">can</i> change position to form questions. We don’t use <i class="i">do</i>/<i class="i">does</i>/<i class="i">did</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Can this</b> really be true?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Does this can really be true?</s></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Can’t you</b> ask for another day off work?</i></p></blockquote></div></div><p class="p">We use <i class="i">can</i> and <i class="i">can’t</i> in question tags:<span class="target"/></p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You can’t take photos inside the museum, <b class="b">can you</b>?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Abby can speak Japanese, <b class="b">can’t she</b>?</i></p></blockquote></div></div>
<div id='ad_contentslot_1' class='am-default contentslot'>
</div>
</div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="can-uses"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Can</i>: uses</h2></div><div class="content"><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Permission</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We often use <i class="i">can</i> to ask for or give permission:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Can</b> I take Daisy for a walk?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Students <b class="b">can</b> use calculators during the exam.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">We use <i class="i">can’t</i> to forbid (say what you must not do):</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You <b class="b">can’t</b> park there.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You <b class="b">can’t</b> just take the day off work. You have to have permission in advance.</i></p></blockquote><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/may"><i class="i">May</i> </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Ability</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We often use <i class="i">can</i> to talk about ability to do something in the present or future:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">can</b> sing one song in Polish.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Can</b> you sleep on your back?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">can</b> go swimming after school tomorrow, if you like.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">We often use <i class="i">can</i> with verbs of perception such as <i class="i">hear, see, smell, taste</i>, and mental process verbs such as <i class="i">guess, imagine, picture, understand</i> and <i class="i">follow</i> (in the sense of ‘understand’):</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">can</b> hear you.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">can</b> see her coming down the road now.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Can</b> you smell something burning?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">can</b> guess why you’re angry.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">can’t</b> follow these instructions for installing this new DVD player.</i> (We can’t understand these instructions.)</p></blockquote></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">General truths</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">can</i> to talk about things which we think are usually, but not always, true:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Reducing cholesterol through diet <b class="b">can</b> be difficult.</i> (It’s not always difficult for everyone, but in general it is difficult.)</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Fireworks <b class="b">can</b> frighten pets.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Swans <b class="b">can</b> be very vicious.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">We don’t normally use <i class="i">could</i> to talk about what we believe to be true in the present.<span class="target"/></p><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Compare</span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Exercise <b class="b">can</b> help reduce stress.</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><p class="p">I believe this is a general truth or fact.</p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Exercise <b class="b">could</b> help reduce stress.</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><p class="p">I see this only as a possibility.</p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Finding a hotel in August <b class="b">can</b> be difficult.</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><p class="p">I believe this is a general truth or <span class="target"/>fact based on my experience or knowledge.</p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Finding a hotel in August <b class="b">could</b> be difficult.</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><p class="p">I see this only as a possibility.</p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/could"><i class="i">Could</i> </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div>
<div id='ad_contentslot_2' class='am-default contentslot'>
</div>
<div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Possibility</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">can</i> to express possibility or to question possibilities:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">can</b> go to Rome in June because both of us have a week off work.</i> (It is possible for us to go to Rome because we don’t have to work in June.)</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Well, how <b class="b">can</b> you be on a diet if you buy so much chocolate?</i> (I don’t think it’s possible that you are on a diet because you still buy lots of chocolate.)</p></blockquote></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Guessing and predicting: <i class="i"><i class="i">can’t</i></i> as the negative of <i class="i"><i class="i">must</i></i></h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">When we want to guess or predict something, we use c<i class="i">an’t</i> as the negative form of <i class="i">must</i>. We use <i class="i">can’t have +</i> -<i class="i">ed</i> form as the negative form of <i class="i">must have +</i> -<i class="i">ed. Can’t</i> and <i class="i">can’t have +</i> -<i class="i">ed</i> form express strong possibility:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Who owns this blue coat? It</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">must</i></b> <i class="i">be yours</i>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">It</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">can’t</i></b> <i class="i">be mine. It’s too big</i>. (A uses <i class="i">must</i> to guess that the coat belongs to B. He sees this as a strong possibility. B uses <i class="i">can’t</i> to express strong negative possibility. The coat is too big, so it isn’t his.)</p></div></div></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Roy</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">must</i></b> <i class="i">have made a lot of money</i>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">He</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">can’t</i></b> <i class="i">have done. He doesn’t even own a house</i>. (A makes a deduction that Roy has made a lot of money. B sees this as very unlikely and so expresses it as a negative possibility.)</p></div></div></blockquote><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/must"><i class="i">Must</i> </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/could"><i class="i">Could</i> </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Requests</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">can</i> as a question form to make requests:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Those cakes look so good. <b class="b">Can</b> I try one?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Can</b> I have your surname?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Can</b> you help me with this form?</i></p></blockquote><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/could"><i class="i">Could</i> </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/requests">Requests </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div>
<div id='ad_contentslot_3' class='am-default contentslot'>
</div>
<div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Reproaches</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">can’t</i> as a question form to ask people to stop doing something we don’t want them to do, or to do something they are not doing which we want them to do:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Can’t</b> you stop making that awful noise?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Why <b class="b">can’t</b> you just be nice to her instead of upsetting her?</i></p></blockquote></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Offers</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">can</i> as a question form to make offers:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Can</b> I help you lift that?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Can</b> we do anything for you?</i></p></blockquote><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/offers">Offers </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div>      </div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="can-past"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Can</i>: past</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>The past of <i class="i">can</i> is <i class="i">could</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">In those days, you <b class="b">could</b> buy everything in the local shop. Now we have to go to the big supermarket for everything.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We asked the security guards if we <b class="b">could</b> go backstage to meet the band.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">When we question the possibility of something in the past, we use <i class="i">can’t have</i> +-<i class="i">ed</i> form:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You <b class="b">can’t have arrived</b> here earlier than me.</i></p></blockquote></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="can-typical-errors"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Can</i>: typical errors</h2></div><div class="content"><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We write <i class="i">cannot</i> as one word:</p></li></ul><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The children <b class="b">cannot</b> be left unsupervised at any time.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">The children can not be left unsupervised</s> <span class="target"/>…</p></blockquote><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p">We use <i class="i">could</i>, not <i class="i">can</i>, to talk about ability in the past.</p></li></ul><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">They <b class="b">could</b> see a light on in the house as they drove past at 10 pm.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">They can see a light on in the house</s> …</p></blockquote></div></div></div></div></article>
</div>
</div>
<div class="clrd">
<div class="mod float-xl">
<div id='ad_btmslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_b' class='am-default '>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cdo-tpl__z cdo-tpl-main__z3 clrd">

</div>

</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Easily confused words</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/above-or-over"><i>Above</i> or <i>over?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/across-over-or-through"><i>Across</i>, <i>over</i> or <i>through</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/advice-or-advise"><i>Advice</i> or <i>advise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/affect-or-effect"><i>Affect</i> or <i>effect</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-every"><i>All</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-whole"><i>All</i> or <i>whole</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/allow-permit-or-let"><i>Allow</i>, <i>permit</i> or <i>let</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/almost-or-nearly"><i>Almost</i> or <i>nearly</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alone-lonely-or-lonesome"><i>Alone</i>, <i>lonely</i>, or <i>lonesome</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/along-or-alongside"><i>Along</i> or <i>alongside</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/already-still-or-yet"><i>Already</i>, <i>still</i> or <i>yet</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/also-as-well-or-too"><i>Also</i>, <i>as well</i> or <i>too</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alternate-ly-alternative-ly"><i>Alternate(ly)</i>, <i>alternative(ly)</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/although-or-though"><i>Although</i> or <i>though</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/altogether-or-all-together"><i>Altogether</i> or <i>all together</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/amount-of-number-of-or-quantity-of"><i>Amount of</i>, <i>number of</i> or <i>quantity of</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/any-more-or-anymore"><i>Any more</i> or <i>anymore</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/anyone-anybody-or-anything"><i>Anyone</i>, <i>anybody</i> or <i>anything</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/apart-from-or-except-for"><i>Apart from</i> or <i>except for</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arise-or-rise"><i>Arise</i> or <i>rise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/around-or-round"><i>Around</i> or <i>round</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arouse-or-rouse"><i>Arouse</i> or <i>rouse</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-or-like"><i>As</i> or <i>like</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-because-or-since"><i>As</i>, <i>because</i> or <i>since</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-when-or-while"><i>As</i>, <i>when</i> or <i>while</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/been-or-gone"><i>Been</i> or <i>gone</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/begin-or-start"><i>Begin</i> or <i>start</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/beside-or-besides"><i>Beside</i> or <i>besides</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/between-or-among"><i>Between</i> or <i>among</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/born-or-borne"><i>Born</i> or <i>borne</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/bring-take-and-fetch"><i>Bring</i>, <i>take</i> and <i>fetch</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/can-could-or-may"><i>Can</i>, <i>could</i> or <i>may</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/classic-or-classical"><i>Classic</i> or <i>classical?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/come-or-go"><i>Come</i> or <i>go?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consider-or-regard"><i>Consider</i> or <i>regard</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consist-comprise-or-compose"><i>Consist</i>, <i>comprise</i> or <i>compose</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/content-or-contents"><i>Content</i> or <i>contents?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/different-from-different-to-or-different-than"><i>Different from</i>, <i>different to</i> or <i>different than</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/do-or-make"><i>Do</i> or <i>make</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/down-downwards-or-downward"><i>Down, downwards or <i>downward?</i></i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/during-or-for"><i>During</i> or <i>for?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/each-or-every"><i>Each</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/east-or-eastern-north-or-northern"><i>East</i> or <i>eastern</i>; <i>north</i> or <i>northern</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/economic-or-economical"><i>Economic</i> or <i>economical</i>?</a>

<li class="section">
<a>Words, sentences and clauses</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-words-clauses-and-sentences">about words, clauses and sentences</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-and-as-expressions"><i>as</i> and <i>as</i> expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/comparing-and-contrasting">comparing and contrasting</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/conditionals-and-wishes">conditionals and wishes</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/linking-words-and-expressions">linking words and expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/questions-and-negative-sentences">questions and negative sentences</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/relative-clauses">relative clauses</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/reported-speech">reported speech</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/so-and-such"><i>so</i> and <i>such</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/word-formation">word formation</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/word-order-and-focus">word order and focus</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Using English</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/discourse-markers">discourse markers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/emphasising-and-downtoning">emphasising and downtoning</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/functions">functions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/numbers">numbers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/people-and-places">people and places</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking">speaking</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/types-of-english-formal-informal-etc">types of English (formal, informal, etc.)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/useful-phrases">useful phrases</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/writing">writing</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Verbs</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-verbs">about verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be-and-be-expressions"><i>be</i> and <i>be</i> expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/common-verbs">common verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/future">future</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/infinitives-and-imperatives">infinitives and imperatives</a>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>modals and modality</a>
<ul>
<li class="current">
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/can"><i>Can</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/could"><i>Could</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/could-may-and-might"><i>Could</i>, <i>may</i> and <i>might</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/dare"><i>Dare</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/had-better"><i>Had better</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/may"><i>May</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/might"><i>Might</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-forms">Modality: forms</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-introduction">Modality: introduction</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-meanings-and-uses">Modality: meanings and uses</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-other-modal-words-and-expressions">Modality: other modal words and expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-other-verbs">Modality: other verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-tense">Modality: tense</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/must"><i>Must</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/ought-to"><i>Ought to</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/shall"><i>Shall</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/should"><i>Should</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/will"><i>Will</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/would"><i>Would</i></a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/passive">passive</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/past">past</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/present">present</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/verb-patterns">verb patterns</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div class="mod mod--dark mod--style2 oflow-hide">
<div class="pad">
<p class="h2 semi-flush alt">Word of the Day</p>
<p class="h4 feature-w-big wotd-hw">taro</p><p>a tropical plant that has a root that is cooked and eaten</p>
</div>
<div class="txt-block txt-block--alt with-icons js-eqh-sticky">
<div class="with-icons__content">
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/taro" class="a--rev a--b">
<span>About this</span> <i class="fcdo fcdo-angle-right" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</a>
</div>
<div class="with-icons__icons">
